awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Software technology to facilitate decentralized coordination across groups working on systemic problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/ commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project creates a platform specifically designed for more democratic online group-to-group collaboration in a distributed system.  This could provide insights into new ways software can support collaboration, democratic infrastructure, and improve current understanding of how to optimize democratic and decentralized IT governance systems more broadly. Once successful, the technology will accelerate the rate of innovation and coordination across multi-disciplinary teams. 

The project is an effort to study how to create software with group-node database architecture relationships. The goal is to create layers of group network formation while balancing scalability with resiliency. The main innovation is a software-based system for decentralized organizations, which will eventually be using a decentralized underlying infrastructure such as distributed web technology or blockchain. This paradigm incorporates (a) social protocols for effective teaming and coalition formation; (b) automation supporting democratic/cooperative organizations working in a distributed network; (c) accelerated information discovery across disciplines and sectors, (d) data science optimization for model thinking for global optimization solutions in complex systems. The platform would also explore fractal and emergent group dynamics, as an opportunity for thousands (if not millions) of tiny experiments regarding the specific nature of group formation, commons coordination, and effective communication for distributed organizations at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our work aims to lower the cost of running democratic organizations and non-hierarchical networks of teams. Socialroots aims to provide essential infrastructure for self-organizing networks tackling humanity's biggest challenges. By making the value-network visible to the network and enabling healthy boundaries that allow both safety and speed of communication, we believe we can dramatically decrease waste and increase coordination capacity for any distributed network of groups. We think this could be a key missing piece of technology in the private-to-public gradient and the key to enabling digital community as well as more efficient democratic structures in organizations and society as a whole

We built a platform that enables a decentralized network of organizations to coordinate across healthy boundaries more easily. In order to enable that, we had to allow for a novel architecture that can support 3+ levels of nesting across sets of groups, discussion containers that can be visible as the same object in any number of groups (at any level), and the architecture itself had to be group-centric instead of people centric to support more complex relationships across more nuanced boundaries in a network of groups.

Our approach is rooted in complex adaptive systems theory and extensive fieldwork interviewing and working with multi-stakeholder organizations and distributed ecosystems. For example,we've observed that multi-layered systems, like beehives, can adapt at the group level, and so support group intelligence better than two-layered systems, like a flock of birds, which only can adapt as individuals. We worked in distributed networks of groups, studied decentralized technology, cooperative systems, and categorical AI to inform our technology. 



Last Modified: 07/19/2024
Modified by: Ana Jamborcic
